disjunctive-syllogism-2 (python sample)ïƒ

Tags: disjunctive-syllogism-2 python sample

See also

math concept | python declaration class | python inclusion class

This page shows how to infer new statements in a theory-elaboration-sequence by applying the disjunctive-syllogism-2 inference-rule.

Usageïƒ

Call the infer_statement method from the inference-rule inclusion class listed in the i (unabridged inference_rules ) property of the theory-elaboration-sequence :

u = pu.create_universe()
t = u.t()
...
# some theory elaboration code
...
t.i.disjunctive_syllogism_2.infer_statement(...)

Sample codeïƒ

import punctilious as pu

# Create a universe-of-discourse with basic objects for the sake of this example.
u = pu.UniverseOfDiscourse(echo=True)
o1 = u.o.declare()
o2 = u.o.declare()
o3 = u.o.declare()
o4 = u.o.declare()
axiom = u.declare_axiom(natural_language='Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes')

# Elaborate a dummy theory with a set of propositions necessary for our demonstration
t1 = u.t(echo=True)
theory_axiom = t1.include_axiom(a=axiom)
phi1 = t1.i.axiom_interpretation.infer_formula_statement(a=theory_axiom,
    p=(o1 | u.r.implies | o3) | u.r.lor | (o1 | u.r.implies | o4))
phi2 = t1.i.axiom_interpretation.infer_formula_statement(a=theory_axiom,
    p=u.r.lnot((o1 | u.r.implies | o4)))

# And finally, use the conjunction-introduction inference-rule:
proposition_of_interest = t1.i.disjunctive_syllogism_2.infer_formula_statement(p_or_q=phi1,
    not_q=phi2, subtitle='The proposition of interest')

import punctilious as pu

# Create a universe-of-discourse with basic objects for the sake of this example.
u = pu.UniverseOfDiscourse(echo=True)
o1 = u.o.declare()
o2 = u.o.declare()
o3 = u.o.declare()
o4 = u.o.declare()
axiom = u.declare_axiom(natural_language='Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes')

# Elaborate a dummy theory with a set of propositions necessary for our demonstration
t1 = u.t(echo=True)
theory_axiom = t1.include_axiom(a=axiom)
phi1 = t1.i.axiom_interpretation.infer_formula_statement(a=theory_axiom,
    p=(o1 | u.r.implies | o3) | u.r.lor | (o1 | u.r.implies | o4))
phi2 = t1.i.axiom_interpretation.infer_formula_statement(a=theory_axiom,
    p=u.r.lnot((o1 | u.r.implies | o4)))

# And finally, use the conjunction-introduction inference-rule:
proposition_of_interest = t1.i.disjunctive_syllogism_2.infer_formula_statement(p_or_q=phi1,
    not_q=phi2, subtitle='The proposition of interest')

Let "U31" be a universe-of-discourse.

Let "T1" be a theory-elaboration-sequence in U31.

Axiom (T1.A1): Let axiom A1 "Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes" be included (postulated) in T1.

Inference rule (axiom-interpretation): Let inference-rule axiom-interpretation defined as "(A2, P1 |- P1)" be included and considered valid in T1.

Proposition (T1.P1): ((o1 ==> o3) or (o1 ==> o4)). Proof: "Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes" is postulated by axiom (A1). ((o1 ==> o3) or (o1 ==> o4)) is a valid formula statement interpreted from that axiom.Therefore, by the  inference rule: (A2, P1 |- P1), it follows that ((o1 ==> o3) or (o1 ==> o4)). QED

Proposition (T1.P2): not((o1 ==> o4)). Proof: "Dummy axiom for demonstration purposes" is postulated by axiom (A1). not((o1 ==> o4)) is a valid formula statement interpreted from that axiom.Therefore, by the  inference rule: (A2, P1 |- P1), it follows that not((o1 ==> o4)). QED

Inference rule (disjunctive-syllogism-2): Let inference-rule disjunctive-syllogism-2 defined as "((P3 or Q1), not(P3) |- Q1)" be included and considered valid in T1.

Proposition (T1.P3) - The proposition of interest: (o1 ==> o3). Proof: ((o1 ==> o3) or (o1 ==> o4)), of the form (P3 or Q1), follows from prop. (P1). P2, of the form not(P3), is given. Therefore, by the  inference rule: ((P3 or Q1), not(P3) |- Q1), it follows that (o1 ==> o3). QED
